note.p: The second derash in Leviticus 10:16 written at the end of the line. The song Ha'azinu in Deuteronomy 32 written in 66, and not 70 lines. It is preceded by six lines with the prescribed initial words, and one blank line; but it is followed by one blank line, eight lines of text, and another blank line.

collation.p: 40 membranes, with wooden rollers and silk, brocade and linen mantle.

layout.p: 153 columns in total, three to six columns per membrane.
Occasional tagin on שעטנזגץ (except at the beginning of Numbers).
Majuscular and minuscular letter in accordance with the rules.
Special shapes of the letter ז, נ, פ and broken ו occur infrequently.
The "puncta extraordinaria" placed on the words fixed by masorah (with a few exceptions).
Several lines and parts of lines written on erasures.

handDesc.summary: Sefardi square script of the 14th century.

acquisition.p: The Harley Collection, formed by Robert Harley (b. 1661, d. 1724), 1st earl of Oxford and Mortimer, politician, and Edward Harley (b. 1689, d. 1741), 2nd earl of Oxford and Mortimer, book collector and patron of the arts. Edward Harley bequeathed the library to his widow, Henrietta Cavendish, née Holles (b. 1694, d. 1755) during her lifetime and thereafter to their daughter, Margaret Cavendish Bentinck (b. 1715, d. 1785), duchess of Portland; the manuscripts were sold by the Countess and the Duchess in 1753 to the nation for £10,000 (a fraction of their contemporary value) under the Act of Parliament that also established the British Museum; the Harley manuscripts form one of the foundation collections of the British Library.

recordHist.source: Manuscript description based on Margoliouth, G.: Catalogue of the Hebrew and Samaritan Manuscripts in the British Museum, London 1965.
